If they removed ward-hops, yeah, Lee would be a better design to the point where Ralanr's statement would make sense. 

However, as it stands, Lee is just about as easy as Maokai, if not easier due to the amount of options you have at any given point.

Not true, at all. Let's take a look at some win rates, shall we?

Lee Sin has around a 43 to 44 percent win rate on players with 1-5 games on him. He then has a 47 percent win rate on people with five to fifteen games on him, it isn't until you get to that past fifteen games point where the win rate even becomes even.

Now Maokai has a 49/50 percent win rate for new players, until you have over 125 games on him, giving you a massive win rate, probably inflated by how few Maokai OTPS there are, meaning that they can have a really good win rate, but it is only like ten players.

So comparing our two win rates, Lee Sin is incredibly low win rate for over half of the players playing him, whereas Maokai is really even throughout.

So Lee Sin is not as easy as Maokai, at least look up some facts before hand.

It takes the average Taliyah player roughly 55 - 105 games to begin average a consistent 52% win rate. 
Even in that scenario it can fluctuate from an average of 45 - 125 games.  
That is the statistics of a skill-based champion.
 
Lee Sin on the otherhand takes an average of 15 - 45 games, to begin an average of the exact same win-rate. 
That is not the statistics of a skill-based champion.

Only in the worst case scenario will a Lee Sin player end in the same position as the best case scenario of a Taliyah player.

Even though Lee Sin is braindead easy, using Taliyah as a comparison is unfair since Taliyah is among the highest mastery curves in the game. Something mid tier like Orianna, Yasuo, Karma or Zyra would be a better comparison

Lee Sin is actually basically a weaker, slightly higher damage but overall less utility form of Rek'Sai in pro play.

Lee Sin has a knock back, but that pales in comparison to a global ult. 

Rek'Sai's ward hop doesn't require wards and also gives her mobility over time where ever she leaves it.

Rek'Sai's Q applies a slow, and her AOE knock up and Tremorsense are much more valuable than Lee Sin's abilities.

And Rek'Sai's clearing is about the same as Lee's. 

They bring largely the same benefit to the table (highly mobile diver) but Rek'Sai is just MORE mobile than Lee Sin.

Rek'Sai's "Ward hop" is significantly slower than Lee Sin's.

Rek'Sai has no slows. Her only CC is the unburrow knockup

Rek'Sai is not more mobile than Lee sin. She has better map mobility, able to get from point A to B faster. Lee Sin has far better in combat mobility. He has two fast dashes to her one slow dash. If she happens to be near an undestroyed tunnel, she can get another one, but that's  mostly luck.

That, and her ult is basically only used to farm camps faster after a recall, or have objective presence from the other side of the map.

She has the worst 'global' presence out of all of the long-ranged skills/mobility.

> They bring largely the same benefit to the table (highly mobile diver) but Rek'Sai is just MORE mobile than Lee Sin.

I'm not contradicting or arguing with you, but both champions (Lee Sin and Rek'Sai) are mobile, but in different ways.

Rek'Sai has a more roam-based mobility, where she can move around a lot, very quickly. On the other hand, Lee Sin has a lot of combat mobility, meaning he is able to use his mobility more in combat to evade damage, reposition, and chase down enemies. With Rek'Sai's mobility in combat, I mostly use it to engage and to chase down enemies after a teamfight. Rek'Sai is pretty far into her mini-rework though, which is focused on changing her into a single-target diver like Lee Sin, so it's possible that her overall gameplay (not just diving) could become more or less similar to Lee Sin.

I'm **just** talking about pro  play though, because that's what OP is talking about. 

In pro play, nothing Lee Sin brings to the table comes close to Tremorsense. That ability is ridiculous. You can see your opponents' movements, you don't need to facecheck and it can't be cleared like a ward. You know which camps you can safely steal and which ones to avoid while in the enemy jungle. You can aim skill shots better when someone ducks into a brush. You can tell when the enemy team is doing dragon. 

Additionally, the out of combat roaming is just better because it means less time spent in base. More often than not pros will use Rek'sai's ult as soon as it comes off CD so they can keep farming without needing to return to the jungle from base. That's a huge chunk of gold and XP Rek'sai has over Lee Sin.
